Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 40116 
July 2006 
 
 
 
 
Support for APEC Fiscal and Financial Initiatives 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  AFMP  –  APEC Finance Ministers Process 
  APEC   –  Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation 
  DMC  –  developing member country

  OREI  –  Office of Regional Economic Integration

Head  M. Kawai  Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI)

Team leader  J. Tsunoda  Senior Financial Sector Specialist, OREI

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In  May  1998,  the  Asia-Pacific  Economic  Cooperation1  (APEC)  Finance  Ministers 
Meeting (FMM) endorsed establishment of the APEC Financial Regulators Training Initiative 
(FRTI) to enhance training efforts for national and regional financial regulators (i.e., within Asia). 
The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been acting as the FRTI Secretariat and financially 
supported  its  training  activities.  Considering  progress  achieved  under  the  FRTI  and  the 
continued need for training in this area, the 12th APEC FMM during 8–9 September 2005 in 
Jeju, Republic of Korea, extended the FRTI for another year and requested a continuation of 
ADB support. At the meeting of the 20th APEC Finance Ministers Technical Working Group 
(TWG) Meeting in Gwangju, Republic of Korea, in June 2005, two new APEC initiatives were 
endorsed: (i) Reform of Financial Sector Initiative (by Australia, People’s Republic of China 
(PRC), Indonesia, Japan, and (ii) Fiscal Management Initiative (by Australia, Indonesia, Viet 
Nam). The two initiatives were introduced at the meeting of the 21st APEC Finance Ministers 
TWG  Meeting  in  Hanoi,  Viet  Nam,  7–9  December  2005,  and  ADB  was  asked  to  provide 
technical support along with the World Bank. The World Bank is expected to provide basic 
policy research as well as lessons learned from experience outside of Asia, while ADB is 
expected to share experiences garnered from within Asia.  
 
2.  This  technical  assistance  (TA)2  is  to  provide  ADB  support  for  these  and  other 
collaborative initiatives coming in the next 2 years under the APEC Finance Ministers Process 
(AFMP). The design and monitoring framework is attached as Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  In  1994,  the  APEC  finance  ministers  started  an  annual  forum  for  APEC  member 
economies  to  exchange  views  and  information  on  regional  financial  developments  and  to 
pursue cooperative programs that promote financial sector development and liberalization. The 
AFMP forum comprises (i) an annual FMM to discuss specific policy themes; (ii) an annual 
APEC  deputies  meeting  preceding  the  FMM;  and  (iii)  semiannual  finance  ministers  TWG 
meetings, which bring relevant experts together for detailed discussions and exchange of ideas 
on the specific AFMP themes, as well as review of ongoing and newly proposed policy initiatives.  
 
4.  Subsequently, the Asian financial crisis exposed a number of structural weakness and 
imperfections  in  the  macroeconomic  frameworks  and  financial  markets  in  the  affected 
economies. Addressing these issues is critical to the resolution of the current problems and 
prevention  of  similar  shocks  in  the  future.  The  adverse  effects  of  the  crisis  created  new 
challenges for APEC economies. Thus, new strategic goals for the AFMP were reviewed and 
agreed  at  the  8th  APEC  FMM  in  Suzhou,  PRC,  in  September  2001.  These  goals,  which 
complement  the  overall  goals  of  APEC,  are  to  promote  sound  and  credible  policies  for 
(i) sustainable and broad-based growth with equity in the APEC region; (ii) good corporate 
governance  and  public  sector  management;  (iii)  stable  and  efficient  financial  markets; 
(iv) greater economic cooperation, integration, and openness among APEC economies; and 
(v) facilitation of economic and technical cooperation within the region in pursuit of these goals.   
 
5.  Since the first APEC FMM in 1994 in Honolulu, United States (US), the ADB President 
has been invited annually to attend these meetings, and ADB staff have participated to help

Philippines; Russian Federation; Singapore; Taipei,China; Thailand; United States; and Viet Nam. 
2  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 10 May 2006.

2 
promote  policy  dialogue.  They  also  provide  knowledge  support  relevant  to  (i)  formulating 
macroeconomic policy for financial stability, (ii) reforming financial market infrastructure for 
financial sector stability and restructuring, and (iii) strengthening supervisory and regulatory 
frameworks for a prudent and effective financial market. Including ADB’s support to the APEC 
FRTI, ADB has assisted these forums through studies, surveys, workshops, and capacity-
building seminars related to the policy agenda and initiatives by the AFMP. ADB has provided 
five TAs.3  
 
6.  APEC FRTI (by the US and ADB). Enhancing training efforts for national and regional 
financial regulators (i.e., within Asia) with the FRTI is essential for financial sector stability. 
These  efforts  are  needed  because  (i)  lack  of  adequate  financial  sector  regulation  and 
supervision was one of the major causes of the Asian financial crisis, and (ii) policy and 
governance issues, and inadequate capacity of banking supervisors and securities regulators 
were identified as key constraints to implementing the best international practices in financial 
sector regulation and supervision in many of the countries affected by the financial crisis. Many 
APEC  economies  and  ADB  developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  have  committed  to 
implementing the core principles for banking supervision and securities regulation developed by 
the  Bank  for  International  Settlements  and  the  International  Organization  of  Securities 
Commissions (IOSCO). 
  
7.  The FRTI has had separate programs for banking supervisors and securities regulators.4 
The banking supervision program5 receives major TA support from the US Federal Reserve 
System and has taken the initiative in providing trainers and seminar materials.6 The securities 
regulation7 program has been under more diversified commitments and used instructors from 
regulatory and other relevant institutions in APEC member economies such as Hong Kong 
Monetary Authority; Monetary Authority of Singapore; and Securities Commission, Malaysia, for 
its training courses.8 The FRTI also developed audiovisual training products covering the core 
areas of banking supervision training (i.e., bank analysis, credit risk analysis, and market risk 
analysis), as well as a web-based self-study course for newly hired securities regulators. The 
work of the FRTI receives oversight through the APEC Advisory Group, representing bank 
supervision and securities regulatory agencies from member countries and other interested 
parties (Advisory Group members for banking are from 14 member countries and for security, 
13 member countries). The present chair country for the Advisory Group is Malaysia since 2004

other donor countries have also provided capacity building and TA to policy makers and regulatory bodies in the 
region.

and internal controls, and on-site supervision, with course content reflecting the Basel Committee's Core Principles.

are held on current regulatory issues such as demutualization and investor education.

and results are reported to Advisory Group members. At the same time, a follow-up evaluation 
query to Advisory Group members is completed 6 months after each seminar. 
 
8.  Initiative on Financial Reform in the APEC Region (by Australia, PRC, Indonesia, 
Japan, and Viet Nam). The aim of the initiative is to discuss how APEC member economies 
have developed and implemented reforms to improve their financial sector. Key issues include 
(i) how  economies  are  coping  with  the  challenge  of  carrying  out  financial  reform,  (ii)  how 
priorities are determined for the implementation of remaining reforms, and (iii) assessment of 
whether gaps exist in expertise and capacity-building efforts. A policy dialogue will be held in 
mid  2006  to  exchange  views  on  the  progress  of  financial  sector  reforms  in  the  member 
economies. The dialogue will cover the broad range of regulatory measures relevant to financial 
stability,  including  capital  standards  and  credit  assessment,  standards  and  practices  in 
prudential supervision, and underlying legal frameworks (including insolvency regimes).  
 
9.  Fiscal Management Initiative (by Australia, Indonesia, and Viet Nam,). The aim of 
the initiative is to build on a broad-ranging fiscal policy report to finance ministers in 2004 by 
undertaking a dialogue on a practical issue—the management of significant off-balance sheet 
risks,  such  as  contingent  liabilities  associated  with  financing  infrastructure  projects  or  with 
explicit guarantees to public or private institutions. The extent to which these risks are reflected 
in government reports and the potential impact on an economy's overall fiscal position are 
issues that are important to the sustainability and transparency of fiscal policy. The initiative will 
discuss  the  measurement,  monitoring,  and  management  of  these  fiscal  risks;  and  the 
consequences of contingent liabilities for the operation of fiscal rules. The first policy dialogue, 
27–28  February  2006,  discussed  international  experience  and  best  practices,  and  shared 
experiences in the Asia and Pacific region.9  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The TA will support AFMP initiatives that seek cooperative regional solutions to fiscal 
management and financial sector issues, and will provide policy advice in the area of regional 
economic cooperation and integration. The TA will help strengthen the capacity of financial 
sector regulators and supervisors in the region through support for regional training efforts and 
seminars. The TA will also support the emerging policy dialogue and technical discussions on 
financial sector reforms and development, fiscal management, and monetary and economic 
stabilization.  ADB’s  active  participation  in  that  process  helps  to  strengthen  the  Asian 
contribution to the dialogue as well as permit ADB staff to learn new approaches to address 
specific policy issues through discussions within a community of experts. These new ideas can 
potentially be useful for ADB’s own policy dialogue and reform programs with the DMCs. Thus, 
to the extent possible, the governance, finance, and trade divisions of the regional departments 
will be encouraged to participate in the workshops, either directly or indirectly, through inputs 
and feedback on ADB’s contributions to those initiatives. This TA is in line with key result areas 
of the Office of Regional Economic Integration for supporting capacity building and institutional 
strengthening,  promoting  regional  economic  policy  dialogue,  and  conducting  research  on 
regional cooperation and integration. 
 
                                                 
9  ADB Mission to the APEC Policy Dialogue Workshop on Fiscal Management headed by Cindy Houser made a 
presentation on Measuring SOE and GBE Worth: The Balance Sheet Approach.

4 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will support the activities initiated by the AFMP. Specific components of the 
activities identified so far are the following:  
 
(i)  APEC  Financial  Regulators  Training  Initiative.  The FRTI has made good 
progress in achieving its two original objectives: (a) strengthening content and 
management of national training programs, and (b) developing regional programs 
for junior and mid-Ievel supervisors and regulators. The FRTI has trained almost 
1,491 participants from APEC and 165 participants from non-APEC economies 
through 28 regional and 13 national courses from 2001 to 2005. The TA will 
continue  to  support  the  APEC  FRTI  for  another  2  years 10   through  the 
development  and  implementation  of  additional  training  courses  for  financial 
regulators and supervisors in DMCs and developed Asian APEC economies, in 
line with training priorities identified by advisory group members. The TA will help 
complete training curricula and materials, and continue to build a critical mass of 
potential trainers in the region. All courses will be open to participants from Asian 
APEC economies and non-APEC DMCs. Training materials and seminar papers 
are provided through the APEC FRTI website at www.adb.org and/or distributed 
directly to DMC financial supervisory authorities and regional training institutions 
such as the South East Asian Central Banks Research and Training Centre, 
whose staff will be invited to join the training courses organized under the TA. 
The TA will also support updating course material, strengthening information 
dissemination  of  the  APEC  FRTI  through  the  website,  and  enhancing 
management of the FRTI advisory group structure through a network of banking 
supervisors and security regulators among Asian APEC economies and non-
APEC DMCs. 
 
The expected results and outputs are (a) at least 250 participants from regulatory 
and  supervisory  agencies  trained in  priority  training  topics  over  2  years,  (b) 
networking among APEC financial regulators on training issues strengthened, 
and (c) course curricula and materials developed and used by national and 
regional training institutions. 
 
(ii)  Initiative on Financial Reform in the APEC Region. Together with the World 
Bank, ADB has been asked to provide technical support on financial reform. An 
immediate requirement is a paper on financial sector reforms and restructuring in 
selected East Asian countries to be presented at a workshop under the financial 
sector initiatives in November 2006, followed by additional papers for workshops 
in 2007. The workshops are open to all APEC members as well as invited guests. 
The expected results and outputs are papers on financial sector reforms and 
restructuring  in  selected  East  Asian  countries  (possibly  covering  the  PRC, 
Indonesia, Viet Nam, and Malaysia)11 to be presented in a series of workshops 
during 2006–2007. 
 
                                                 
10  Extending the APEC FRTI is endorsed annually by the APEC FMM. However, this TA proposes ADB support for 
another 2 years with the provision of strong recommendation by the US and APEC Advisory Group member 
countries.  
11  The PRC, Indonesia, and Viet Nam are chosen as they are initiating the Financial Reform Initiative. Malaysia is 
chosen as an example of successful financial reform.

5 
(iii)  Fiscal Management Initiative. Together with the World Bank, ADB has been 
asked  to  provide  technical  support  on  fiscal  management.  An  immediate 
requirement is a paper on measurement issues relating to assessing the fiscal 
risks arising from state-owned enterprises in selected APEC member economies 
to be presented in a workshop in November 2006.  Similar requirements are 
expected in 2007. The workshops are open to all APEC members as well as 
invited guests. For the first Policy Dialogue on Fiscal Management held in Hanoi, 
Viet Nam; Cambodia and Lao People’s Democratic Republic attended as guests. 
The expected results and outputs are papers on assessing fiscal risks in APEC 
member economies to be presented in a series of workshops during 2006–2007. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $800,000. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The cost will cover remuneration and travel expenses of 
international and national consultants, travel expenses of seminar resource persons, upgrading 
of training programs, and other miscellaneous expenses. The TA cost estimates and financing 
plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  ADB will be the TA Executing Agency and the Office of Regional Economic Integration 
will implement the TA, in close collaboration with the Advisory Group of the APEC FRTI.  
 
14.  The TA activities will be implemented with the assistance of international and national 
consultants. The TA will support the APEC FRTI activities by (i) conducting regional training 
seminars for financial regulators and supervisors on priority topics, (ii) organizing advisory group 
meetings for selecting topics and curricula, (iii) disseminating information on the seminars and 
facilitating the network of financial regulators and supervisors through the project website, and 
(iv) upgrading the training program. The TA will also finance the engagement of consultants for 
(i) preparing papers for the Initiative on Financial Reform in the APEC Region and the Fiscal 
Management Initiative; and (ii) attending the initiatives’ seminars and conferences, and making 
presentations. The TA will require approximately 16 person-months of international and 23 
person-months of national consulting services. The TA will be implemented over 2 years starting 
from July 2006. All consultants and all resource persons will be engaged in accordance with 
ADB's  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  Consultants  will  be  engaged  as  individual 
consultants.  The  scope  of  work  and  outline  terms  of  reference  for  the  consultants  are  in 
Appendix 3.   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis for 
Support for APEC Fiscal and Financial Initiatives, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Collaborative  initiatives  mandated  by  the  Asia-Pacific  Economic  Cooperation  (APEC) 
Finance Ministers Process may require some activities other than those identified in these outline 
terms of reference, in which case suitable modifications will be made to fulfill the commitments and 
responsibilities of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
 
A.   Consultant for Financial Sector Reform (international, 4 person-months) 
 
2.  The primary focus is to conduct an in-depth evaluation of financial sector reforms that have 
been completed or are under way in the APEC economies using a comparative framework to 
determine 
 
(i)  how economies are coping with the challenge of carrying out financial sector reform,  
 
(ii)   how priorities are determined for the implementation of further reforms, and 
 
(iii)   whether gaps in expertise and existing capacity-building efforts exist and need to be 
filled to ensure the progress of reforms.  
 
B.   Consultant for Fiscal Management (international, 4 person-months) 
 
3.  The main focus is to assess the management of off-balance sheet fiscal risks arising out of 
contingent fiscal liabilities as well as other potential topics in fiscal management. The consultant 
will evaluate the identification, measurement, monitoring, and management of these fiscal risks. 
The evaluation should include measurement issues related to assessing the fiscal risks arising 
from state-owned enterprises in selected APEC members.  
 
C.   Financial Sector Supervision Training Experts (international, 8 person-months) 
 
4.  The experts will 
 
(i)  manage  the  structure  of  the  advisory  group  of  the  APEC  Financial  Regulators 
Training Initiative (FRTI), which will include 
 
(a)  preparation and facilitation of advisory group meetings; 
 
(b)  conduct and analysis of regular surveys on the status of national training 
efforts and emerging training needs; 
 
(c)  coordination with other regional and global training providers; and  
 
(d)  collection and dissemination of information on regional training resources, 
materials, and events including through the ADB external APEC website; 
 
(ii)  prepare progress reports on the FRTI for the APEC Finance Ministers Process;  
 
(iii)  organize  and  facilitate  regional  training  seminars  for  banking  and  securities 
regulators under the FRTI;

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
(iv)  organize the transfer of training programs and products developed under the FRTI 
to regional and national training institutions; 
 
(v)  liaise  with  regulatory  agencies  in  developed  APEC  economies  regarding  the 
provision of instructors and with the host country, finalize training programs, act as a 
facilitator for the outlined seminars, and prepare concise evaluation reports; 
 
(ix)  prepare guidelines for developing case studies for training purposes (hypothetical 
and based on actual cases); and  
 
(x)  conduct a survey identifying the required area of computer-based training among 
financial regulators; and prepare a plan to transfer the existing course material into 
computer-based training.  
 
D.   Resource Persons for Financial Regulatory Training Programs (international)  
 
8.  The resource persons will 
 
(i)  participate in the training courses/seminars, 
 
(ii)   prepare and make presentation(s) during the training courses/seminars (topics to be 
determined in discussion with ADB), and 
 
(iii)   participate in panel discussions for seminars, as requested. 
 
E.    Project Specialist (national, 20 person-months) 
 
9.  The expert will 
 
(i)  contribute to the preparation of papers and presentation materials for the APEC 
initiatives supported by ADB by collecting, compiling, and analyzing data and other 
information; 
 
(ii)   undertake Internet searches in relation to work for the APEC initiatives supported by 
ADB; 
 
(ii)  maintain and upgrade the project website of APEC initiatives for enhancing the 
network among financial regulators and liaise with ADB’s Department of External 
Relations on postings; and 
 
(iv)   help with the work of the Secretariat for the APEC FRTI, which includes organizing 
periodic regional meetings and seminars, coordinating with APEC training experts, 
and updating the training materials and other relevant information.
